text: From time to time I see the question raised from bettors about how many bets they need to make from a certain strategy before they can conclude that the strategy is +EV. Isn't this a question well suited for statistical hypothesis testing? So, given a history of bets, you define a confidence interval, and this analysis could either conclude that the strategy is +EV within the given confidence interval or not. Has anybody tried such an approach?

elements.text: From time to time I see the question raised from bettors about how many bets they need to make from a certain strategy before they can conclude that the strategy is +EV. Isn't this a question well suited for statistical hypothesis testing? So, given a history of bets, you define a confidence interval, and this analysis could either conclude that the strategy is +EV within the given confidence interval or not. Has anybody tried such an approach?

text: Of course and yes but when the answer is that you need a sample size much larger than the number of matches that are played or the number of races that take place over a reasonable time frame then you need to be a bit more nuanced about it

elements.text: Of course and yes but when the answer is that you need a sample size much larger than the number of matches that are played or the number of races that take place over a reasonable time frame then you need to be a bit more nuanced about it

text: <@U01M0B57D0C> has joined the channel

Interesting Mo, I guess the required sample size would increase for longer odds. But if you had some ten thousands of bets, I guess this would be doable? The reason I ask is actually tax related, as the tax regulations in my country depends on if the profits are "random" or if they are "suitable for making a profit over time".

elements.text: Interesting Mo, I guess the required sample size would increase for longer odds. But if you had some ten thousands of bets, I guess this would be doable? The reason I ask is actually tax related, as the tax regulations in my country depends on if the profits are "random" or if they are "suitable for making a profit over time".

text: Yes, required sample size will definitely depend on the average odds that you're betting at. You'll also have to be careful about dependency between bets, because if those ten thousand bets are placed on some much smaller number of events then your effective sample size will be the number of events

elements.text: Yes, required sample size will definitely depend on the average odds that you're betting at. You'll also have to be careful about dependency between bets, because if those ten thousand bets are placed on some much smaller number of events then your effective sample size will be the number of events

This idea usually gets brought up in the context of deciding whether back test results are good or not but it sounds like you have a history of bets actually placed?

elements.text: This idea usually gets brought up in the context of deciding whether back test results are good or not but it sounds like you have a history of bets actually placed?

text: Yes, I have a 10-12 year history of bets, out of which the last 7-8 years are stored in a database, so a lot of data for statistics in there.

elements.text: Yes, I have a 10-12 year history of bets, out of which the last 7-8 years are stored in a database, so a lot of data for statistics in there.

text: So, I am not longer wondering if my strategy is profitable :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: So, I am not longer wondering if my strategy is profitable

text: I think that's an important distinction and it should be much easier to say whether this shows you have a systematic edge than try to use 7 year old back test data to justify rolling your strategy out into production

elements.text: I think that's an important distinction and it should be much easier to say whether this shows you have a systematic edge than try to use 7 year old back test data to justify rolling your strategy out into production

text: Good point, that is maybe something I can use here, a strategy that worked a few years ago has no guarantee to work in the future...
